canonical_explanation.text: A vector has both magnitude and direction. Vectors can be represented as a⃗ = aᵢî + aⱼĵ + aₖk̂. The dot product a⃗·b⃗ = a₁b₁+a₂b₂+a₃b₃ = |a⃗||b⃗|cosθ gives a scalar. The cross product a⃗×b⃗ = (a₂b₃-a₃b₂)î - (a₁b₃-a₃b₁)ĵ + (a₁b₂-a₂b₁)k̂ gives a vector perpendicular to both. The scalar triple product [a⃗ b⃗ c⃗] = a⃗·(b⃗×c⃗) equals the volume of the parallelepiped formed by the three vectors.
rules: Area of triangle = ½|a⃗×b⃗|; Area of parallelogram = |a⃗×b⃗|

questions.question_text: A vector with magnitude zero is called:
questions.explanation_correct: A vector whose magnitude is zero is called a zero vector (or null vector), denoted 0⃗. It has no definite direction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A zero vector has magnitude 0 and is denoted 0⃗. A unit vector has magnitude 1.

questions.question_text: If a⃗ = 2î + 3ĵ + 6k̂, then |a⃗| equals:
The unit vector in the direction of a⃗ = 3î - 4ĵ is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: First find |a⃗| = 5, then divide each component by 5 to get the unit vector.

questions.question_text: Two vectors are equal if and only if they have the same magnitude and the same direction.
questions.explanation_correct: Two vectors are equal when they have both the same magnitude and the same direction, regardless of their initial points.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Equal vectors must have identical magnitude and direction. Position does not matter for free vectors.

questions.question_text: The position vector of a point P(2, -3, 5) is:
questions.explanation_correct: The position vector of P(x, y, z) with respect to the origin is xî + yĵ + zk̂ = 2î - 3ĵ + 5k̂.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The position vector is formed directly from the coordinates: 2î - 3ĵ + 5k̂.

questions.question_text: If a⃗ = î + 2ĵ + 3k̂ and b⃗ = 2î + ĵ - k̂, then a⃗ + b⃗ equals:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Add corresponding components: (1+2)î + (2+1)ĵ + (3-1)k̂ = 3î + 3ĵ + 2k̂.

questions.question_text: If a⃗ = 4î - ĵ + 2k̂, then 2a⃗ equals:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Multiply each component by the scalar 2: 2(4) = 8, 2(-1) = -2, 2(2) = 4.

questions.question_text: Two vectors a⃗ and b⃗ are collinear if:

options.text: a⃗ = λb⃗ for some scalar λ

questions.explanation_correct: Two vectors are collinear (parallel) if one is a scalar multiple of the other, i.e., a⃗ = λb⃗ for some scalar λ.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Collinear vectors are parallel, meaning one is a scalar multiple of the other. a⃗·b⃗ = 0 means they are perpendicular, not collinear.

questions.question_text: The direction cosines of the vector 2î - 2ĵ + k̂ are 2/3, -2/3, and ___.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The magnitude is 3. The third direction cosine is the k̂ component divided by the magnitude: 1/3.

questions.question_text: The position vector of the point dividing the line segment joining A(1, -2, 3) and B(3, 4, -1) internally in the ratio 2:1 is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Section formula for internal division in ratio m:n gives (mb⃗ + na⃗)/(m+n). Here m=2, n=1.

questions.question_text: If the vectors 2î + aĵ - k̂ and 6î - 3ĵ + bk̂ are collinear, then the values of a and b are:
questions.explanation_correct: For collinear vectors, the ratio of corresponding components must be equal: 2/6 = a/(-3) = (-1)/b. From 2/6 = 1/3, we get a/(-3) = 1/3, so a = -1. Also (-1)/b = 1/3, so b = -3.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Collinear vectors have equal component ratios: 2/6 = 1/3. So a/(-3) = 1/3 gives a = -1, and (-1)/b = 1/3 gives b = -3.

questions.question_text: The vector joining the points A(1, 2, 3) and B(4, 6, 3) is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: The vector from A to B is found by subtracting position vector of A from that of B: (4-1)î + (6-2)ĵ + (3-3)k̂.

questions.question_text: The negative of the vector 3î - 5ĵ + 2k̂ is:
questions.explanation_correct: The negative of a vector reverses the sign of each component: -(3î - 5ĵ + 2k̂) = -3î + 5ĵ - 2k̂.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Negate every component: 3 becomes -3, -5 becomes 5, 2 becomes -2.

questions.question_text: The dot product of a⃗ = î + 2ĵ + 3k̂ and b⃗ = 2î - ĵ + k̂ is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Multiply corresponding components and add: 1(2) + 2(-1) + 3(1) = 2 - 2 + 3 = 3.

questions.question_text: If a⃗·b⃗ = 0, then the vectors a⃗ and b⃗ are:
questions.explanation_correct: a⃗·b⃗ = |a⃗||b⃗|cosθ. If the dot product is zero (and both vectors are non-zero), then cosθ = 0, so θ = 90°. The vectors are perpendicular.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Zero dot product (for non-zero vectors) means the angle between them is 90°, i.e., they are perpendicular.

questions.question_text: The value of î·î is:
questions.explanation_correct: î·î = |î|² = 1² = 1. The dot product of a unit vector with itself equals 1.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The dot product of any unit vector with itself is 1. î·î = 1.

questions.question_text: The dot product î·ĵ = 0.
questions.explanation_correct: î and ĵ are perpendicular unit vectors along the x-axis and y-axis respectively. Since they are perpendicular, î·ĵ = 0.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Perpendicular unit vectors have zero dot product. î·ĵ = î·k̂ = ĵ·k̂ = 0.

questions.question_text: The angle between a⃗ = î + ĵ and b⃗ = ĵ + k̂ is:
The projection of a⃗ = 2î + 3ĵ - 6k̂ on b⃗ = 2î - ĵ + 2k̂ is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Projection of a⃗ on b⃗ = (a⃗·b⃗)/|b⃗| = -11/3.

questions.question_text: If a⃗ = 3î + ĵ - k̂ and b⃗ = î - 3ĵ + k̂, then a⃗·b⃗ equals:
For what value of λ are the vectors a⃗ = 2î + λĵ + k̂ and b⃗ = î - 2ĵ + 3k̂ perpendicular?
questions.explanation_incorrect: Set dot product to zero: 2 - 2λ + 3 = 0, so λ = 5/2.

questions.question_text: If |a⃗| = 3, |b⃗| = 4, and a⃗·b⃗ = 6, then the angle between a⃗ and b⃗ is ___ degrees.
questions.explanation_incorrect: cosθ = 6/12 = 1/2, giving θ = 60°.

questions.question_text: If |a⃗| = 2, |b⃗| = 3, and the angle between them is 60°, then |a⃗ + b⃗| equals:
The midpoint of the line segment joining A with position vector 2î + 3ĵ + 4k̂ and B with position vector 4î + ĵ - 2k̂ has position vector:
questions.explanation_incorrect: The midpoint position vector is the average of the two position vectors: ((2+4)/2, (3+1)/2, (4-2)/2) = (3, 2, 1).

questions.question_text: The cross product î × ĵ equals:
questions.explanation_correct: By the right-hand rule and the definition of cross product of unit vectors: î × ĵ = k̂.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The standard result is î × ĵ = k̂, ĵ × k̂ = î, k̂ × î = ĵ (cyclic order).

questions.question_text: If a⃗ × b⃗ = 0⃗ (and both are non-zero), then a⃗ and b⃗ are:
questions.explanation_correct: a⃗ × b⃗ = |a⃗||b⃗|sinθ n̂. If the cross product is zero and both vectors are non-zero, then sinθ = 0, so θ = 0° or 180°. This means the vectors are parallel.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Zero cross product (for non-zero vectors) means the vectors are parallel (angle is 0° or 180°).

questions.question_text: The cross product a⃗ × b⃗ is a vector perpendicular to both a⃗ and b⃗.
questions.explanation_correct: By definition, the cross product a⃗ × b⃗ = |a⃗||b⃗|sinθ n̂, where n̂ is perpendicular to both a⃗ and b⃗ (right-hand rule).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cross product gives a vector that is perpendicular to the plane containing a⃗ and b⃗.

questions.question_text: If a⃗ = 2î + k̂ and b⃗ = î + ĵ + k̂, then a⃗ × b⃗ equals:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using the determinant formula: î(0-1) - ĵ(2-1) + k̂(2-0) = -î - ĵ + 2k̂.

questions.question_text: The area of the parallelogram with adjacent sides a⃗ = î + 2ĵ + 3k̂ and b⃗ = î - 3ĵ + k̂ is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cross product = 11î + 2ĵ - 5k̂. Magnitude = √(121+4+25) = √150 = 5√6.

questions.question_text: If a⃗ = 3î + ĵ - 2k̂ and b⃗ = î - 3ĵ + 4k̂, then a⃗ × b⃗ equals:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using the determinant: î(4-6) - ĵ(12+2) + k̂(-9-1) = -2î - 14ĵ - 10k̂.

questions.question_text: The area of the triangle with two sides represented by a⃗ = î + 2ĵ and b⃗ = 3î - k̂ is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cross product = -2î + ĵ - 6k̂, magnitude = √41. Area of triangle = (1/2)√41.

questions.question_text: The scalar triple product of a⃗, b⃗, c⃗ is denoted as:
questions.explanation_correct: The scalar triple product [a⃗ b⃗ c⃗] = a⃗·(b⃗ × c⃗). It gives a scalar equal to the volume of the parallelepiped.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The scalar triple product is defined as a⃗·(b⃗ × c⃗). Note that b⃗·c⃗ is a scalar and cannot be crossed with a vector.

questions.question_text: Three vectors are coplanar if and only if their scalar triple product is:
questions.explanation_correct: Three vectors a⃗, b⃗, c⃗ are coplanar if and only if [a⃗ b⃗ c⃗] = a⃗·(b⃗ × c⃗) = 0. This means the volume of the parallelepiped is zero.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Coplanarity means the vectors lie in the same plane, so the volume of the parallelepiped they form is zero, i.e., scalar triple product = 0.

questions.question_text: The scalar triple product of a⃗ = î, b⃗ = ĵ, c⃗ = k̂ is:
questions.explanation_correct: [î ĵ k̂] = î·(ĵ × k̂) = î·î = 1. The unit vectors along the three axes form a right-handed system with triple product 1.
questions.explanation_incorrect: ĵ × k̂ = î. Then î·î = 1.

questions.question_text: Find the scalar triple product [a⃗ b⃗ c⃗] where a⃗ = î + 2ĵ, b⃗ = 2î + ĵ + k̂, c⃗ = k̂.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Evaluate the 3x3 determinant: 1(1-0) - 2(2-0) + 0(0-0) = 1 - 4 = -3.

questions.question_text: Are the vectors a⃗ = î - 2ĵ + 3k̂, b⃗ = -2î + 3ĵ - 4k̂, c⃗ = î - 3ĵ + 5k̂ coplanar?

options.text: They are coplanar only if scaled

questions.explanation_correct: [a⃗ b⃗ c⃗] = |1 -2 3; -2 3 -4; 1 -3 5| = 1(15-12) + 2(-10+4) + 3(6-3) = 3 - 12 + 9 = 0. Since the scalar triple product is 0, the vectors are coplanar.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Compute the determinant: 1(15-12) + 2(-10+4) + 3(6-3) = 3 - 12 + 9 = 0. Scalar triple product is 0, so vectors are coplanar.

questions.question_text: If a⃗ = î + ĵ + k̂, then the magnitude of a⃗ is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sum of squares of components: 1 + 1 + 1 = 3. Magnitude = √3.

questions.question_text: If |a⃗| = 4, |b⃗| = 2, and the angle between a⃗ and b⃗ is π/3, then |a⃗ - b⃗|² equals:
If a⃗ and b⃗ are unit vectors and |a⃗ + b⃗| = √3, then the value of |a⃗ - b⃗| is:
The cross product of a vector with itself, a⃗ × a⃗, equals:
questions.explanation_correct: a⃗ × a⃗ = |a⃗||a⃗|sin(0°) n̂ = 0⃗, since the angle between a vector and itself is 0° and sin(0°) = 0.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cross product of any vector with itself is the zero vector since sin(0) = 0.

questions.question_text: If |a⃗| = 3, |b⃗| = 4, and the angle between them is 30°, then |a⃗ × b⃗| equals:
The area of the parallelogram with diagonals d₁⃗ = 2î + ĵ - k̂ and d₂⃗ = î - 3ĵ + 4k̂ is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: For a parallelogram with diagonals d₁⃗ and d₂⃗, area = (1/2)|d₁⃗ × d₂⃗| = √131/2.

questions.question_text: If a⃗ × b⃗ = 3î - 2ĵ + 6k̂, then the area of the triangle formed by a⃗ and b⃗ as adjacent sides is:
If a⃗ = 2î + 2ĵ - k̂, then |a⃗| = ___.
If [a⃗ b⃗ c⃗] = 5, then the volume of the parallelepiped formed by a⃗, b⃗, c⃗ is:
questions.explanation_correct: The volume of the parallelepiped equals the absolute value of the scalar triple product: |[a⃗ b⃗ c⃗]| = |5| = 5.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The scalar triple product gives the signed volume. The volume = |scalar triple product| = 5.

questions.question_text: Find [a⃗ b⃗ c⃗] where a⃗ = 2î - ĵ + k̂, b⃗ = î + 2ĵ - k̂, c⃗ = 3î + ĵ + 2k̂.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Evaluate the 3x3 determinant: 2(4+1) + 1(2+3) + 1(1-6) = 10 + 5 - 5 = 10.

questions.question_text: If a⃗ = î - 2ĵ + 3k̂ and b⃗ = 3î - 2ĵ + k̂, then (2a⃗ + b⃗)·(a⃗ - 2b⃗) equals:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Compute 2a⃗ + b⃗ = 5î - 6ĵ + 7k̂ and a⃗ - 2b⃗ = -5î + 2ĵ + k̂. Dot product = -25 - 12 + 7 = -30.

questions.question_text: a⃗ × b⃗ = -(b⃗ × a⃗) for any two vectors a⃗ and b⃗.
questions.explanation_correct: The cross product is anti-commutative: a⃗ × b⃗ = -(b⃗ × a⃗). Reversing the order of vectors in a cross product changes the sign of the result.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cross product is anti-commutative. Swapping the order introduces a negative sign.

questions.question_text: For what value of λ are the vectors a⃗ = î + 2ĵ + 3k̂, b⃗ = 2î + ĵ - k̂, c⃗ = λî - ĵ + k̂ coplanar?
questions.explanation_incorrect: Set the scalar triple product to zero: -10 - 5λ = 0, so λ = -2.
